title: Introduction to Binary
description: Learn about the binary number system that computers use.

sections.title: What is Binary?
sections.content:
Binary is the base-2 number system, using only two digits: 0 and 1. These digits are called 'bits' (binary digits). This system is perfect for computers because electrical circuits can easily represent two states: ON (1) or OFF (0).

Just like decimal uses powers of 10, binary uses powers of 2:

• 2⁰ = 1 (ones place)
• 2¹ = 2 (twos place)
• 2² = 4 (fours place)
• 2³ = 8 (eights place)
• 2⁴ = 16 (sixteens place)
• And so on...

Each position's value doubles as you move left! Let's count in binary:
0 = 0
1 = 1
10 = 2 (one 2, zero 1s)
11 = 3 (one 2, one 1)
100 = 4 (one 4, zero 2s, zero 1s)
101 = 5 (one 4, zero 2s, one 1)
110 = 6
111 = 7
1000 = 8

Notice how we need more digits in binary to represent the same value as decimal? That's because we only have 2 digits to work with instead of 10!

exercise.problem: What comes after 101 when counting in binary?
exercise.explanation: 101 is 5 in decimal. The next number is 6, which is 110 in binary (one 4, one 2, zero 1s).
hints: Think about what 6 looks like in binary

exercises.problem: How many unique digits does binary use?
exercises.explanation: Binary is base 2, so it uses exactly 2 digits: 0 and 1

exercises.problem: In binary 1010, how many bits are there?
What is the largest value you can represent with 3 bits?
exercises.explanation: 3 bits can represent 111 in binary, which equals 4+2+1 = 7 in decimal

questions.questionText: Binary can only use the digits 0 and 1.
questions.explanation: Correct! Binary (base 2) uses only two digits: 0 and 1. Any other digit would make it a different number system.
hints: How many digits does base 2 have?

questions.explanation: Computers use electrical circuits that have two states: ON (representing 1) and OFF (representing 0). Binary's two digits perfectly match these two states.
hints: Circuits are either ON or OFF

questions.questionText: Each binary digit is called a ____.
questions.explanation: Binary digits are called 'bits', which is short for 'binary digit'. It's the smallest unit of data in computing.

questions.questionText: What is the value of the leftmost position in 4-bit binary?
questions.explanation: In a 4-bit binary number, positions from right to left are: 1, 2, 4, 8. So the leftmost position has value 8 (which is 2³).

questions.questionText: How many different values can 3 bits represent?
questions.explanation: With 3 bits, you can represent 2³ = 8 different values (from 000 to 111, or 0 to 7 in decimal).
hints: Formula: 2^n where n is number of bits

questions.questionText: In binary, each position value is double the position to its right.
questions.explanation: True! Binary uses powers of 2, so moving left means multiplying by 2: ...16, 8, 4, 2, 1. Each position is exactly double the one to its right.
